hints.content: Equivalent fractions cover the same area of the whole.

Let's represent $\dfrac{3}{6}$ using a visual model.

![rectangle with 3 of 6 equal parts shaded, with each part labeled 1 sixth.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/cdea38c22eaf93cee9be36e4cef6a4edeaf17d80)

We need $4$ parts in the equivalent fraction to cover the same area as $\dfrac{3}{\blueD{6}}$.

![rectangle with 3 of 6 equal parts shaded, with each part labeled 1 sixth.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/cdea38c22eaf93cee9be36e4cef6a4edeaf17d80)
![same-sized rectangle with 4 of an unknown number of equal parts shaded, each labeled 1 over unknown number.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/d6b7e0533c80adc575dc9ed52b57c0a931dcb52c)

How many equal parts should the equivalent fraction have?

We need $\maroonD{8}$ equal parts per whole.

![rectangle with 3 of 6 equal parts shaded, with each part labeled 1 sixth.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/cdea38c22eaf93cee9be36e4cef6a4edeaf17d80) 
![same-sized rectangle with 4 of 8 equal parts shaded, with each part labeled 1 eighth.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/470468218d6701200fd8166e407053f307f62445)

$\dfrac{3}{6} = \dfrac{4}{\maroonD{8}}$

question.content:
**What value of $c$ makes the equation true?**

 $\dfrac{3}{6} = \dfrac{4}{c}$

$c=$ [[â˜ƒ numeric-input 1]]
